CFRs of SARS have typically been estimated by dividing the number of deaths by the total number of cases. This method is sufficient for an advanced epidemic. However, the method is not accurate at an early stage of an epidemic, particularly when the time from infection to recovery or death is not brief, relative to the duration of the epidemic, as is currently true with SARS. The method underestimates the CFR because it does not account for a proportion of currently infected persons’ dying from the disease. A more accurate method would be to divide the number of deaths by the total number of deaths plus the number of persons who recovered. By applying this method to publicly available WHO data (1), the cumulative CFR estimates appear more stable, relatively constant within a country (aside from Taiwan, which is in the earliest stage of its epidemic) but varying considerably among countries (Figure 1).

https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/9/8/03-0334_article

CFRs of SARS have typically been estimated by dividing the number of deaths by the total number of cases. This method is sufficient for an advanced epidemic. However, the method is not accurate at an early stage of an epidemic, particularly when the time from infection to recovery or death is not brief, relative to the duration of the epidemic, as is currently true with SARS. The method underestimates the CFR because it does not account for a proportion of currently infected persons’ dying from the disease. A more accurate method would be to divide the number of deaths by the total number of deaths plus the number of persons who recovered. By applying this method to publicly available WHO data (1), the cumulative CFR estimates appear more stable, relatively constant within a country (aside from Taiwan, which is in the earliest stage of its epidemic) but varying considerably among countries (Figure 1).

The method underestimates the CFR because it does not account for a proportion of currently infected persons’ dying from the disease. A more accurate method would be to divide the number of deaths by the total number of deaths plus the number of persons who recovered. By applying this method to publicly available WHO data (1), the cumulative CFR estimates appear more stable, relatively constant within a country (aside from Taiwan, which is in the earliest stage of its epidemic) but varying considerably among countries (Figure 1).

quote.msg:
其實個爭議點係
(1) 如果用"現在死亡個案/累積確診個案"黎計，就會低估死亡率，呢個原因好易理解，因為累積確診個案中，又未死又未治癒既人當中，其實係有人會死
(2) 另一方面，如果用"現在死亡個案/(現在死亡個案+現在治癒個案)"黎計，其實係會高估死亡率，原因係治癒係需要比死亡較長嘅時間，所以會有同一時間染病，治癒既人被忽略，而死亡又有考慮既情況

但如果睇睇而家既數據，有~3500人治癒，~900人死亡，總共~4400，其實就係兩星期前(1/27)既累積確診數目，亦即係話呢兩星期內既病例其實都未settle down，應該都唔考慮先岩
而真正計法應該係追蹤用1/27前嘅每一個個案，再用果堆人最後生定死黎計
但基本上由於缺乏資訊，其實係計唔到，而只可以話>2.1%，<21%

你呢個estimate既方法係我寫嘅第二種方法，但我認為係biased嘅
因為成個病程大概十四日，呢十四日內死嘅死，唔死嘅到十四日後先叫治癒
啫係話由確診到治癒要十四日，但到死亡係少過十四日

咁結果呢個方法攞到嘅治癒嘅sample只有從第一日到十四日前咁長嘅時間但死亡嘅就會除左由第一日到十四日前嘅sample外，仲多左呢十四日內死嘅sample
所以為左去除呢個bias就需要cutoff喺十四日之前確診嘅個案
